I know a lot about this game and have been following it closely.
 
 Here's a good forum if you'd like to research it more... 
 
 As to whether it is a good aid for explaining evolution I would say no.
 
 In reality you as 'the god' have complete control over the creature and it's appearance as it develops -- the game itself is a cartoonish parody of the stages of development of life from single celled organisms to intelligent nation building species (and beyond).
 
 Your creature's species succeeds because of your interaction rather than because it's design is the most optimum. The game then does not simulate evolution rather it uses it as part of the 'story line' because it is you and not natural selection who gets to decided whether the animal grows another limb or not.
 
 Having said all this I'm very much looking forward to it's release... projected to be in the third quarter of next year. :(

 No, there's many stages but it's only in the early ones that you control one creature (it lays and egg and then you control the offspring). In the later stages you control entire towns of creatures and eventually multiple planets with different colonies. Indeed you will be able to have tanks, planes, ships, sub marines, and space ships under your control fighting other civilisations like an RTS.
 
 Imagine this is a single player game but a master server harvests the player created content (like your creature and it's society and culture) to populate other people's game.
 
 Indeed, when you start the game the game will download creatures based on the needs of the environment. So say the ecosystem needs a couple of species of small carnivores, a medium and large herbivore, and one large super carnivore, the game will log onto the master system and pick said creatures from all those uploaded by other people.
 
 Every time you find a new planet in the simulated galaxy the computer will automatically populate it with suitable creatures created by everyone else in the world who is playing the game.
 
 Black & White 2 looks really good but I'd far rather have Spore going by what I know about it at the moment.
